SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST) is a rare form of stroke
Although increased intracranial pressure is a well-described complication of CVST, hydrocephalus has rarely been reported
CASE: We present the case of a 49-year-old woman who presented with one week of headache, vomiting, and progressive neurologic deterioration leading to coma
Head CT and MRI identified extensive CVST and accompanying hydrocephalus
She was treated with systemic anticoagulation as well as mechanical and pharmacologic endovascular thrombolysis
An external ventricular drain (EVD) was not inserted given the potential bleeding risk while anticoagulated
Subsequently, she made an excellent recovery and had a normal neurologic exam at long-term follow up
CONCLUSION: Hydrocephalus is a rare complication of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
Treatment of hydrocephalus with an EVD may not be necessary if interventions are undertaken to urgently recanalize thrombosed venous sinuses
